posts.name:
Jerry Rassamni
Jerry Rassamni
posts.content:
AI-Generated Visions: Inspiring Futures 

Imagine a teacher showing students who they could becomeâ€”literally! Using AI-generated images, this teacher creates personalized visuals of students' future selves, aligned with their dreams and goals.

 A student dreaming of being a scientist sees themselves in a lab, making groundbreaking discoveries.
 An aspiring artist sees her gallery filled with stunning artwork.
 A future athlete envisions their grand prize-winning moment, medals around their neck.

 ğ—ªğ—µğ˜† ğ—§ğ—µğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ— ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€:
 Making Dreams Tangible: Students see their aspirations brought to life, inspiring confidence and belief in their goals.
 Boosting Motivation: By visualizing success, students feel empowered to work towards achieving it.
 Expanding Possibilities: AI becomes more than a tech toolâ€”it becomes a catalyst for hope and self-belief.

 ğ—¬ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—§ğ—µğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—´ğ—µğ˜ğ˜€:
What do you think of this innovative motivational approach? Could it revolutionize how we teach and learn? Letâ€™s discuss below!

 Follow me for more insights on AI and education innovations!

comments.commentText: I have heard many stories of working class and neurodiverse kids especially being told by 'career counsellors' what they will not be able to achieve. An approach that non-judgmentally took into account what kids think they might like to do and projected a concrete image might be particularly beneficial for kids without role models in their environment. My only concern is that this projects a superficial image; it's about looks, not essence. DallE's vision of a scientist involves a labcoat, but most scientists wear regular clothes - which might be a plus if you're a bright kid who's not into uniforms... As usual AI is one of many handy tools and needs supplementing with dialogue and open-minded, informed adults who care.

Great post! I think this innovative approach has the potential to revolutionize how we teach and learn. By using AI-generated images to visualize success, students can develop a growth mindset and feel more motivated to work towards achieving their goals. Additionally, this approach can help expand students' possibilities by showing them what they can become and inspiring them to dream big. Overall, I believe that AI has the power to transform education and help students reach their full potential. Thanks for sharing!

posts.name:
Chloe Lawson
Chloe Lawson
posts.content:
Iâ€™m (mostly) a remote worker. 

And the biggest argument against remote working is the lack of socialisation.

But thankfully, in an increasingly connected world, there are SO many ways to socialise both online and in-person.

As a remote worker, Iâ€™ve found the perfect balance between working independently and staying socially connected.

Here's how:

â†’ Work alongside a buddy on communication platforms (like Discord).

â†’ Work in a coffee shop for some ambient socialisation.

â†’ Jump on regular video calls and catch ups with colleagues.

â†’ Make time after work to connect with friends and family.

â†’ Meet up with other remote workers.

â†’ Join community groups on Facebook.

â†’ Occasionally visit the office (if you have one).

â†’ Join a coworking space.

How do you stay social when working remotely?

comments.commentText: Plus the fact I live with my partner and 2 doggies helps massively  do you have any pets?!
Chloe Lawson I don't have pets myself, but I can certainly appreciate the joy they bring. Your dogs must make home life so wonderful!  How long have you had them?
My whole thing is lack of socialization, leave me be with my cats :D
Emily Kimmings heavily relatable (but with dogs)
Chloe Lawson I have them too :D but they want to leave the house

posts.name:
Megan Lieu
Megan Lieu
posts.content:
Last year I left my corporate job and never looked back.

In every job Iâ€™ve held in my career, Iâ€™d always felt like an imposter.

But it wasnâ€™t the type of imposter syndrome that made me feel like I was inadequate.

It was the type of imposter syndrome that made me feel like I was living two different lives between work and life.

Because I could never get behind the idea of building someone elseâ€™s dream.

So I kept switching jobs each year thinking that a new environment would drown out the thoughts of being but a cog in the machine.

Until I couldnâ€™t do it anymore.

So here are my tips if you want to turn your passions into your career one day (so that you donâ€™t end up paying for someone elseâ€™s Lambo!):

1. Assess your skills vs market demand

â†³ Identify what you excel at and are passionate about vs there are gaps in the market.

2. Build your financial safety net

â†³ Aim to save enough to cover your expenses for 3-6 months so that you have the freedom to explore opportunities without the immediate pressure of generating income.

3. Start small, test the waters

â†³ Start your own projects while youâ€™re still employed, e.g. volunteer, freelance work, so that you can gauge your interest and the viability of your business idea without fully committing right away.

4. Leverage social media

â†³ Creating valuable content like tutorials, tips, or industry insights on platforms like LinkedIn will allow you to position yourself as an authority in your field.

2025 is the year we start building toward our own dreams.

Follow mefor more tips like these!

comments.commentText: Bonus tip: embrace the imposter syndrome. Everyone else around you feels it too. The difference between those who succeed and those who donâ€™t is that the former use the doubts as fuel instead of discouragement

Megan Lieu 100%!!!!!! 
ï¸ Accept doubt as a normal emotion not something to be feared!
ï¸ See doubt as an opportunity to reflect on your skills - learn and GROW. 
ï¸ Diminish doubt by taking however small steps and build momentum.
ï¸ Overcome doubt - the self kind - stay persistent - keep pushing forward when the doubt tries to hold you back
ï¸ Embrace doubt as a catalyst to growth
ï¸ TRANSFORM DOUBT a source of discouragement into a powerful motivator.

The most important thing to know if you want to take the leap?

Step #3, Megan Lieu.

Take. Small. Steps. Now.

That's it.

---

You don't have to dive into the deep end right away.
You don't have to quit your cushy job.

Start putting in the reps today.
To set yourself up for freedom tomorrow.

Trust me, it works!
And if it doesn't work, pivot!
Mary Southern Starting small and taking intentional steps is the best way to build momentum and make the leap feel less overwhelming.
Megan Lieu or you find an uber rich dude and marry into mega wealth.

posts.name:
Eric Imel
Eric Imel
posts.content:
Automation â‰  Continuous Improvement 

I've been reading the Elon Musk biography. It talked about when Elon started working with Tesla.

Elon pushed to automate everything!

Take all the humans out of the process!!!

(I started chuckling to myself because I knew what would happen next...)

Tesla was starting to experience quality issues and countless production delays. Elon went to the production floor and started watching the robots. He found the automation was struggling with their assigned tasks like installing nuts and bolts.

As they tried to troubleshoot the robots, they realized humans could complete that task faster than the robot AND with zero defects.

One by one each process was reevaluated. If a human could outperform the robot at that given task, the robot was drug out to the parking lot and a human took it's place.

With Lean we teach that automation is the very last thing a process needs.

Humans can see opportunities for improvement, detect and prevent defects, and adapt to changes in the process.

Moral of the story:

Before you invest in pricey automation...

INVEST IN YOUR PEOPLE FIRST!!!

After all, humans are the only investment that APPRECIATES over time.

comments.commentText:
One of my biggest points is to this exactly when we talk about automation. Take AI for example. It's really cool, but if companies were to have invested the billions into their own people's education and training they would have gotten better results. 

If the work can't be properly automated don't push it. Just let new tools augment your work force. I don't understand the race to replace everyone. IF you took that to the logical extreme only businesses would generate any income and then go under because there would be no one left to consume any products.

We live on a planet full of people trying to find meaning and purpose. Why are we in such a rush to remove the humanity from everything with zero increase to QoL.

Robin de Jongh do you believe money is the only thing keeping your people from your competitor? If they're the best people around then why not pay for them like your competitor is willing to? Just something to think about.

What I also say, there is no danger for robots to get self consciousness because they are machines. The only problem that can happen is abstraction layers of knowledge which will seem like they got it but new humans being involved will not understand it. That's why I hope who initially started it thought about that. If I re-read what I wrote, maybe they can have it produced from initial people not sharing the knowledge. So, it is a danger if initial people didn't think about it, or I would say if it was written on some paper and got lost.

Rene Fuller I know about as much about AI as I do Chinese calculus!  What I do know is AI seems to only work so long as there is a steady stream of somebody else's intellectual property to feed it. It's a problem that will have to be addressed sooner or later.

posts.content:
Top hack to get yourself to the next level faster,

Itâ€™s the who not the how that counts. 

Who you surround yourself with matters more than you think.

Surround yourself with people who:

 Lift you higher.
 Inspire you to dream bigger.
 Call you out (with love) when youâ€™re playing small.

The truth is, thereâ€™s no room in your life for people who dim your light.

You deserve to be in spaces where others see your value, where they believe in you, even when you forget to believe in yourself.

The ones who challenge you, encourage you, and remind you of your power.

Theyâ€™re out there, waiting to help you rise. ï¸

Tag the women who lift you up and remind them how much they mean to you today! 

Need an accountability buddy?

comments.commentText:
Heather Monahan
Greetings From India. 


Try new things, step out of your comfort zone, take risks, do things in ways you've never done them before, ask for help, surround yourself with self-actualized people, become obsessed with the fact that you have one go-round on this planet as the you that is you, and realize how precious and important it is not to squander that.
Sunil. Sharma. Itâ€™s all about stepping out and giving it your all in this one precious life. Keep shining!
Heather Monahan

Absolutely true. I admire your positive attitude and uplifting messages-it's such a gift to those around you. However, once you take that step and surround yourself with like-minded individuals, your world transforms for the better.

posts.name:
Matt Gray
Matt Gray
posts.content:
Traveling is the best teacher of the 21st century.

10 life lessons Iâ€™ve learned as a digital nomad:

1. Travel is the best mentor

I was in Japan for 2 months.

The:

â€¢ Sites
â€¢ Culture
â€¢ Way of living

Are a whole new world to me.

It's difficult to step out of your comfort zone - but you learn to accept change as you travel.

It's the secret path to mental resilience.

2. Appreciate different cultures

All humans really just want:

â€¢ Love
â€¢ Family
â€¢ Freedom
â€¢ Friendship
â€¢ Happiness

Everything else is secondary.

So embrace the sameness.

It's the very fiber of people that transcends languages and borders.

3. Pack Light, Gain More

I live out of 1 suitcase and 1 bag.

The more things, the more baggage - literally and figuratively.

But when you pack light, you realize how little you truly need to be happy.

Don't let your possessions possess you.

4. Make friends with strangers

In 2023, I was living in Puerto Escondido for 6 months.

One day, at a cafe, I met a woman who brightened up my day.

I asked her out - now she's my girlfriend and we're traveling the world together.

So treat every person you meet like they could be a lifelong friend.

5. Travel Will Frazzle

For 2 days after I land somewhere new, I'm always anxious.

But that's okay.

I focus on:

â€¢ Finding a gym
â€¢ Getting out into nature

And being patient with myself.

After 48 hours, I know my feeling of anxiety will pass.

6. Learn to think outside of the box

"It's easier for me to get ready for a game on the road because you're expected to lose.

That's a challenge that perks my competitive juices."

- Michael Jordan

I play better away, too.

I get constant creativity, inspiration, and focus from new places.

7. Maintain Balance

Running successful businesses while traveling every 3 months is a juggling act.

Make sure to balance:

â€¢ Personal growth
â€¢ Business growth
â€¢ Relationships

Sometimes one comes at the expense of another and that's okay.

Balance wins in the long run.

8. Build Relationships

Quality > Quantity

I've met people who've changed my business - and life.

â€¢ Georgi in Bosnia
â€¢ Michael in Florida
â€¢ Brennan in Australia

The best bit?

I now work with these people in Founder OS.

Widen your talent pool to the entire world.

9. The Kaleidoscope Effect

When you travel, you'll see people living like you'd never have imagined.

You realize the echo chamber you lived in - and take on wildly different perspectives.

Now you'll see challenges from multiple angles, leading to unique, out-of-the-box solutions.

10. Be a Lifelong Learner

The more you read, the more you realize how little you know.

Travel is the same;

The more you travel, the more you realize how little you've experienced.

â€”

Enjoy this? ï¸ Repost it to your network and follow Matt Gray for more.

Want to Learn The Growth Strategy Behind The Most Successful Online Businesses?

Join my free live Workshop on January 16th (72 hours away) to steal my homework:

comments.commentText: Insightful, Matt. Getting rid of the echo chamber opens so many opportunities for growth. Youâ€™ll be tested beyond your wildest imaginations, but youâ€™ll also be learning more than you can ever be dreaming of learning.

we can give all the right ingredients, all the right sunlight and warmth and good soil,

posts.name:
Dr. Deepak Motwani
Dr. Deepak Motwani
posts.content:
Back in 2014, this company went head-to-head with Samsung Electronics, becoming the worldâ€™s No. 2 smartphone brand.ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡³

â‚¹11,000 crore in revenue, 22% market share. Ads everywhere. Phones in every hand.

I am talking about Micromax.

At the heart of it all was Rahul Sharma, the man who dared to dream big.
But dreams have a way of crashing.

> The 4G revolution blindsided Micromax, leaving warehouses full of 3G phones no one wanted.

> Chinese brands flooded the market with better, cheaper options. Innovation stalled.

By 2018, Micromax had lost its edgeâ€”revenues crashed to â‚¹4,345 crore, and profits tanked 97%.

Most people wrote Micromax off.

But not the entrepreneurial spirit in Rahul...Instead of calling it quits, he doubled down:

ï¸ Acquiredâ€™s factory to back a "Make in India" comeback.

ï¸ Launched, Indiaâ€™s first AI-enabled electric bike, and exited with a sale to.

ï¸ Now, with, a semiconductor venture with Taiwanâ€™s Phison, heâ€™s betting big on Indiaâ€™s tech future.

Remember, in business, survival isnâ€™t the goal. Evolution is.

I, for one, am curious to see where he goes next. :)

comments.commentText: Such an inspiring story of resilience and vision! Rahul Sharmaâ€™s journey shows that true entrepreneurs donâ€™t just survive setbacksâ€”they evolve and come back stronger. From leading Micromax to pioneering electric bikes and now venturing into semiconductors. Excited to see how MiPhi Semiconductors contributes to the â€˜Make in Indiaâ€™ initiative and shapes the tech landscape. A true example of turning challenges into opportunities!
Ram Maurya, This is going to be the another masterpiece by Rahul Sharma.
Once a fighter always a fighter
Rajesh Yadav, Some core qualities actually defines and build a person.

posts.name:
Doug Landis
Doug Landis
posts.content:
Here are a few thoughts about what not to say when someone has endured the devastation that is happening in LA (or that happened in Florida, New Orleans, North Carolina or anywhere in the world). 

1) Don't offer something specific (e.g. I have some extra jackets, would you like them?) because then you put the person in the position of having to say no to you when they are already overwhelmed. Offering broad support is so much easier: I'm here. Whatever you need. Anytime.

2) Don't offer support that requires them to be somewhere at a specific time. They are living each day as it comes and while your offer to bring dinner at 7pm on Thursday is generous, they don't know where they'll be at 7pm or whether they'll be interested in dinner.

3) Don't ask them for the specifics. What did you lose is the worst question you can ask.

4) Whatever you do, don't ask to see pictures of their burnt-down home, and don't visit their burnt property unless you're specifically invited. This is extremely painfulâ€”like looking at a dead carcass of your memories.

5) The worst question and comments are those that somehow imply they could've done more. For example, don't casually mention "my friends in Altadena hosed down their house and their house was spared." or "My friends just cleared the brush from their house last year so their house is fine."

6) Don't tell them about other people who have it worse. Their pain is their own. Your compassion comes from listening, not telling.

7) Don't "look on the positive" to them. Don't say "at least you're all safe. That's more important than things." That implies they don't already know that. Believe me, they do!

8) Don't add to their grief. When I told one friend my house had burned, she broke down sobbing and I had to console her. This is not the time to break down about your grief in their loss.

9) Don't tell them that this loss is the universe/God telling them something. If this is your belief, hold it to yourself. No one going through this wants to hear someone else interpret what the universe/God is telling them or that there is a lesson you think they need to learn.

10) The natural tendency is to try to learn from what happened by asking detailed questions that will keep us safe in the future. Don't do that. Don't ask if they evacuated on time or their smoke alarms went off or if they hosed down their house.

Simply tell them you are grateful they are safe. You are there for them, whatever they need. And let them tell you their story when they're ready.

comments.commentText:
Such a powerful list and important reminder. Iâ€™m sorry for what youâ€™ve been through that taught you all these lessons but grateful youâ€™re sharing it. 

Iâ€™ll add one more thing. Put a reminder in your phone to reach out at regular intervals in the future to just check in, tell them youâ€™re thinking of them and offer support.

And always put an annual reminder in your calendar. This day and time of year will be painful for years to come. Everyone else will move on, but theyâ€™ll be reminded of the loss every year. Just sending a text to say youâ€™re thinking of them will mean SO much.

This is all true for every kind of loss, pain, or grief.

Doug Landis, wise words that I'm afraid will fall on plenty of deaf ears. One in particular is the incoming President who seems to be leaning into your #5. And then insulting local leadership for not doing enough. Really? 

Exacerbated by 8 months of dry conditions, those firefighters are facing fires with hurricane winds. So a previous comment from the incoming President that had they had just "raked their forests" none of this would have happened. Oh, and there's doubling down on #5.

The outgoing President has been called the Consoler in Chief, which may make the losses that much better, but at least better than being scolded. But on a positive note, when disasters strike, people genuinely want to help, and that's what makes up strong. I'm in MN was heard that a group of firefighters from northern MN, where we do see a few forest fires, has been sent to help.
